comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Poor copy of four Grumman A-6A Intruder flying in formation, all in gull gray and white with unpainted radomes and black glare shield over nose. At side of windshields in black are Modex numbers in 500 range. Medieval knights helmet with plume emblem on front upper portion of vertical tail used by VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ & code NH of CVW-11 in center of tail. The aircraft of VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ are identified as: A-6A Intruder 155713 VA-52 Modex 503 A-6A Intruder 155714 VA-52 Modex 504 A-6A Intruder 155715 VA-52 Modex 505 A-6A Intruder 155718 VA-52 Modex 510 A 1970 -1971 record for the planes in the 'flickr' pic found in pages of this 'GO!NAVY' internet website: www.gonavy.jp/CVW-NHf.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW11-NH1970.html The info confirms individual aircraft identities, and that eight Intruder, all in the same serial number sequence flew with the squadron without loss during that time. VA-52 equipped with A-6A was part of CVW-11 (code NH) operating from CVA-63 USS KITTY HAWK between November 6, 1970 & July 17, 1971 for a Vietnam War deployment. Online copy of USS KITTY HAWK 1970-1971 Cruise Book: www.navysite.de/cruisebooks/cv63-71/index.html VA-52 webpage within online copy of USS KITTY HAWK 1970-1971 Cruise Book: www.navysite.de/cruisebooks/cv63-71/086.htm Declassified USS KITTY HAWK 1970-1971 Command History on internet: www.history.navy.mil/shiphist/k/cv-63/1971.pdf Below is a heavily edited and condensed version of the 'Command History' with corrected grammar. USS KITTY HAWK First line period 8 to 29 December 1970. Second line period on Yankee Station 13 January to 3 February. Strikes were flown against interdiction targets in Laos and South Vietnam. KITTY HAWK arrived Subic Bay, Philippines 5 February for upkeep period before departing for Hong Kong on 9 February, arriving 12 February. Weighed anchor18 February & arrived back on Yankee Station 21 February. KITTY HAWK launched aircraft into the battle of Lam Son 719 immediately upon return. Lam Son 719 was a South Vietnamese ground offensive into Laos to cut off supply routes from the RVN border to Tchepone, Laos and to capture or destroy immense supply dumps hidden in the area by North Vietnamese - before onset of the southwest monsoon season. Heavy reaction by the North Vietnamese revealed vulnerable targets to strike aircraft including tanks, trucks and troops in transit. CVW-11 sorties then swept into North Vietnam against surface to air missile support bases in 'Fracture Cross Alpha', a joint USAF/US Navy operation conducted on 21 March that destroyed or damaged the objectives. KITTY HAWK on the line thirty nine days from 21 February until 31 March when Lam Son 719 ended. KITTY HAWK left line on 1 April for Subic Bay & arrived 3 April, leaving 7 April for Yankee station for fourth line period lasting April 10 to 25. After a 'Blue Tree' Reconnaissance RA-5C took fire over Quan Lang Airfield North Vietnam CVW-11 aircraft attacked anti aircraft artillery sites and destroyed two MiG-21 Fishbed aircraft sitting on airstrip alert. KITTY HAWK returned Subic Bay April 27-30. During fifth line period 'Special Operations' were conducted from 4-16 May. On 16 May KITTY HAWK left Yankee Station for Sasebo, Japan. Enroute was Exercise Blue Sky air defense exercise in Taiwan with the Nationalist Chinese Air Force. Arrived Sasebo on 21May & departing 26 May to return to Yankee Station for sixth and final line period of the deployment between 30 May & 23 June. From 26-30 June, KITTY HAWK moored at Leyte Pier, NAS Cubi Point in Subic Bay, Philippines and took on provision for transit east . On 1 July KITTY HAWK got underway for Hawaii. Five days out on 5 July four Soviet Tu 95 Bear "D" aircraft overflew KITTY HAWK on a surveillance mission. F-4Js intercepted them over l00 Nautical Miles from the ship and all were escorted throughout the transit. In Hawaii 11-12 July, carrier underway again early on 13 July. KITTY HAWK arrived at homeport San Diego on 17 J u l y 1971. This '1971 Timeline' provides more background info: udornrtafb.tripod.com/id61.html ……………………………………………………………………………………………. Info on A-6A/E Intruder 155713 This aircraft still exists as an open air museum exhibit. Bu No 155713 was originally built as an A-6A, later converted to A-6E plus a further uprate to A-6E ‘TRAM’. Possibly from a 1968/1969 production batch, A-6A 155713 was officially purchased by the US Navy on 10 January 1969. 1980 record for A-6E 155713: www.gonavy.jp/CVW9-NG1980.html A-6E 155713 was with VA-165 'Boomers' as Modex 506 a part of CVW-9 (code NG) embarked on CV-64 USS CONSTELLATION from February 26 to October 15, 1980 for Exercise RIMPAC'80, voyaging across then the Western Pacific and Indian Ocean. 1985 picture of A-6E 155713: www.airfighters.com/photo/62218/L/USA-Navy/Grumman-A-6E-I... A-6E ‘TRAM’ Intruder 155713 VA-165 'Boomers' Modex 506 code NG of CVW-9 USS KITTY HAWK. Andrews AFB (Washington Naval Air Facility) March 1985 A-6E ‘TRAM’ 155713 was retired to the desert ‘boneyard’ at the then AMARC via Davis Monthan AFB near Tucson Arizona on 17 November 1993. Given AMARC inventory code AN5A0082 and placed in AMARC West Area 4, possibly Row 2. It is recorded with a phenomenal (for a US Navy carrier associated aircraft) 7969 Flight Hours, 1480 Catapult launches (CATS) and 1486 carrier arrested landings (TRAPS). October 1994 picture of A-6E 155713 in storage at the then AMARC near Tucson Arizona: www.airliners.net/photo/USA---Navy/Grumman-A-6E-Intruder/... A-6E 155713 appears to have been with the Pacific coast based Fleet Requirements Squadron VA-128 'Golden Intruders’ based at NAS Whidbey Island, Washington State. Wearing Modex 562 and outline of squadron emblem with code NJ on tail. Short AMARC code 5A082 on fuselage. Picture dated October 1994. A-6E 155713 is seen just under a year after retirement to AMARC in November 1993 and still untouched by protective spraylat. Four years later on 16 April 1998 A-6E 155713 was allocated on government loan to the nearby Pima Air & Space Museum where it is now on display. Nine pictures of A-6E 155713 after retirement and as a museum exhibit: www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?regsearch=155713 Four ‘flickr’ pics of A-6E 155713 as a museum exhibit: www.flickr.com/photos/jwm1049/4551721889/ www.flickr.com/photos/matthewphx/3179057936/ www.flickr.com/photos/25558228@N07/4178392135/ www.flickr.com/photos/24526864@N03/3213309791/ A-6E Intruder 155713 Pima Air & Space Museum, Tucson, Arizona. ……………………………………………………………………………………………. Info on A-6A/E Intruder 155714 A 1981 'flickr' color pic of A-6E 155714: www.flickr.com/photos/jackmcgo210/4758292277/ 155714 was built as an A-6A and later converted to A-6E. A 1972-1973 record for A-6A 155714: www.gonavy.jp/CVW2-NE1972.html This was on board CVA-61 USS RANGER between November 16, 1972 & June 22, 1973 when A-6A 155714 was with VA-145 Swordsmen as Modex 504 when part of CVW-2 code NE for a Vietnam War deployment and was heavily involved in attacking North Vietnamese targets throughout. A scale model enthusiast discussion page specifically mentioning A-6A 155714 in context whilst deployed with VA-145 as immediately above: www.arcforums.com/forums/air/index.php?showtopic=67987&am... Nov. 72-June 73 Ranger cruise, three VA-145 Swordsmen A-6As were configured with belly-mounted PAVE Knife pods [NE 503-155711, NE 504-155714, and NE-505-155715]. Noted configurations for the latter included PAVE Way I Mk 84 LGBs on the outboards and AERO 1C fuel tanks on the inboards or PAVE Way I Mk 83 LGBs on the inboards and MER-mounted Mk 82 LDGPs on the outboards. The above source was discovered to be from “A-6 Carrier-Borne Bomber", a book by Robert F. Dorr, which may be down loaded from the internet. 1973 monochrome picture of A-6A 155714: www.gonavy.jp/bbs2-a6f.html Click on picture above caption titled A-6A 155714/NF-506 (1973) It appears that as A-6A 155714 was equipped with Pave Knife it was further test flown on the ranges at NAS China Lake California after return from its 1972-1973 deployment: www.chinalakealumni.org/1973.htm 1973 picture of A-6A 155714 at NAS China Lake Test Center California: www.chinalakealumni.org/IMAGES/1973/155714%20A-6A%2013FEB... VA-145 Intruder BuNo 155714, NE-504, Pave Knife, China Lake, 13 February 1973. Official U.S. Navy photo. Note PAVE KNIFE pod on centerline and angled Modex 504. (Use slider to scroll down page to locate picture and click on to view) 1973 to 1977 record for A-6A 155714 with VA-115 'Arabs' as Modex 506: www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1973.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1974.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1975.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1976.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1977.html Some time between October 1973 & December 1977 A-6A 155714 flew with VA-115 as Modex 506… In 1977 it was replaced by an A-6E Intruder. This was as part of permanently forward deployed air wing CVW-5 (code NF) based at NAF Atsugi in Japan, flying from CV-41 USS MIDWAY, also forward deployed. After return from Japan to the USA A-6A 155714 was placed into the update program, emerging as an A-6E. This 1979 picture includes A-6E 155714: www.airliners.net/photo/USA---Marines/Grumman-A-6E-Intrud... VA-52 ‘Knightriders’. Modex 516. tail code NL CVW-15. USS KITTY HAWK. Andrews AFB Maryland, May 1979. 1979 record for A-6E 155714 www.gonavy.jp/CVW15-NL1979.html May 30, 1979 to February 25, 1980 A-6E 155714 with VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ was Modex 505 whilst aboard CV-63 USS KITTY HAWK on a Western Pacific deployment. Tail code NL of CVW-15. 1981 record for A-6E 155714: www.gonavy.jp/CVW15-NL1981.html From April 1 to November 23, 1981 A-6E 155714 was again with VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ as Modex 505 as part of CVW-15 using code NL when embarked on CV-63 USS KITTY HAWK for another WestPac cruise. Perhaps during 1982 A-6E 155714 was updated further to A-6E ‘TRAM’ configuration with a Hughes 'Target Recognition and Attack Multisensor' turret containing a Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR), laser designator and laser receiver for target recognition and delivery of laser guided weapons. Between 1983 & 1984 A-6E 155714 is recorded with the US Marine Corps within Marine Aircraft Group Twelve (MAG-12) forward based at MCAS Iwakuni, Japan: www.gonavy.jp/usmc/05/usmc0504.html A-6E 155714 Modex 09 was VMA(AW)-224 ‘Bengals’ (code WK) ( using A-6E TRAM ) from 20 April to Oct.1983 Then between Oct.1983 & April1984 A-6E TRAM 155714 was with VMA(AW)-332 ‘Moonlighters’ (code EA) as Modex 09: www.gonavy.jp/usmc/05/usmc0504.html It seems upon arrival back in the USA. A-6E 155714 TRAM was transferred to test squadron VX-5 as Modex 22 tail code XE from this inventory of all aircraft used at China Lake: www.chinalakealumni.org/Aircraft.htm (use slider to scroll down to 'Intruder' to identify and view record) 155714 A-6A VA-145 504 NE 1973….. brought up to A-6E standards; 155714 A-6E. VX-5. XE-22 . 1987. VX-5 < 07/13/87 1987 picture of A-6E 155714 at NAS China Lake Test Center California: www.chinalakealumni.org/1987.htm www.chinalakealumni.org/IMAGES/1987/155714%20A-6E%20ddJUN... VX-5 A-6E Intruder BuNo 155714, XE-22, China Lake, June 1987. Photo by Bob Niedermeier. It is not yet known from internet sources what was the eventual fate of A-6A/E 155714. There is no known record of it being retired to AMARC storage in Arizona. The aircraft may have been stored then scrapped at a Naval Air Depot. Further info that may reveal much more on the service history of A-6A/E 155714 might possibly be accessed by use of the US Freedom of Information Act by ANY interested citizen. foia.navy.mil/OnlineFoiaRequestForm2.asp ……………………………………………………………………………………………. Info on A-6A/E Intruder 155715 155715 was built as an A-6A and later converted to A-6E A 1972-1973 record for VA-145 Swordsmen: www.gonavy.jp/CVW2-NE1972.html This was on board CVA-61 USS RANGER between November 16, 1972 & June 22, 1973 when A-6A 155715 would have been with VA-145 Swordsmen as Modex 505 while part of CVW-2 code NE for a Vietnam War deployment heavily involved in attacking North Vietnamese targets throughout. A scale model enthusiast discussion page specifically mentioning A-6A 155715 in context whilst deployed with VA-145 as immediately above: www.arcforums.com/forums/air/index.php?showtopic=67987&am... Nov. 72-June 73 Ranger cruise, three VA-145 Swordsmen A-6As were configured with belly-mounted PAVE Knife pods [NE 503-155711, NE 504-155714, and NE-505-155715]. Noted configurations for the latter included PAVE Way I Mk 84 LGBs on the outboards and AERO 1C fuel tanks on the inboards or PAVE Way I Mk 83 LGBs on the inboards and MER-mounted Mk 82 LDGPs on the outboards. The above source was discovered to be from “A-6 Carrier-Borne Bomber", a book by Robert F. Dorr, which may be down loaded from the internet. 1973 to 1977 record for A-6A 155715 with VA-115 'Arabs' as Modex 507: www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1973.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1974.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1975.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1976.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1977.html Some time between October 1973 & December 1977 A-6A 155715 stayed with VA-115 as Modex 507… In 1977 it was replaced by an A-6E Intruder. This was as part of permanently forward deployed Air Wing CVW-5 (code NF) based at NAF Atsugi in Japan, flying from CV-41 USS MIDWAY, also forward deployed. A-6A 155715 was once chosen as subject by a model aircraft decal company: modelingmadness.com/scotts/decals/super/72/ss72128.htm Note drawings of four Intruder, one of which is A-6A 155715 when with VA-115 'Arabs' as Modex 507. “A-6A NF-507 S/N155715 VA-115 High Visibility Superscale 72-128” USS Midway based VA-115 aircraft with yellow fin tip and black fin. Red intake splitter plate and tank fins are green. After return from Japan to the USA A-6A 155715 was placed in the A-6E update program. 1981-1982 record for A-6E 155715 with VA-165 ‘Boomers’: www.gonavy.jp/CVW9-NG1981.html From October 20, 1981 to May 23, 1982 A-6E 155715 of VA-165 as Modex 507 with tail code NG CVW-9 flew from CV-64 USS CONSTELLATION while on on a WestPac, Indian Ocean voyage. 1981 color picture of A-6E 155715: jetphotos.net/viewphoto.php?id=5641236&nseq=305 A-6E Intruder 155715 VA-165 Modex 507 tail code NG of CVW-9 on transit flight line Naval Air Station Oceana, Virginia Beach, VA. October 2, 1981 1982 color picture of A-6E 155715: www.abpic.co.uk/photo/1271510/ Grumman A-6E Intruder, VA-165 'Boomers' Modex 507 tail code NG of CVW-9 Seen over NAS Lemoore California, 21st October 1982. 1986-1987 record including A-6E 155715: www.gonavy.jp/CVW15-NL1986.html A-6E 155715 was with VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ as Modex 511 tail code NL of CVW-15. This was aboard CVN-70 CARL VINSON some time between August 12, 1986 & February 5, 1987 for a WestPac Indian Ocean and Arabian Gulf deployment on ‘GONZO’ Station. Commercially available slide of A-6E 155715 from 1987: www.mar.co.uk/ Input CM37365 in ‘Search’ box on top right of webpage to view entry. Original Slide 155715/NL511. A-6E. VA-52 onCV70 87 £2.00 A-6E 155715 was with VA-52 ‘Knightriders’ as Modex 511 tail code NL of CVW-15 on board CVN-70 USS Carl Vinson in 1987. From internet sources it’s not yet known what was the eventual fate of A-6A/E 155715. There is no known record of it being retired to AMARC storage in Arizona. The aircraft may have been stored then scrapped at a Naval Air Depot. Further info that may reveal much more on the service history of A-6A/E 155715 might possibly be accessed by use of the US Freedom of Information Act by ANY interested citizen. foia.navy.mil/OnlineFoiaRequestForm2.asp ……………………………………………………………………………………………. Info on A-6A/E Intruder 155718 A-6E Intruder 155718 within another ‘flickr’ pic: www.flickr.com/photos/nicanair/341065676/ A-6E 155718 VA-55 'Warhorses' Modex 504, tail code AK of Carrier Air Wing Thirteen (CVW-13) in low viz gray with wings folded. Intruder 155718 was originally built as an A-6A and later modernized to A-6E. 1970 color picture including A-6A 155718 commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A-6As_VA-52_over_USS_Kitt... Two Grumman A-6A Intruder BuNo 155717, 155718 of VA-52 Knightriders in flight over their carrier, USS Kitty Hawk (CVA-63), off Vietnam on 15 November 1970. VA-52 was assigned to Attack Carrier Air Wing 11 aboard the Kitty Hawk from 6 November 1970 to 17 July 1971. U.S. Navy National Museum of Naval Aviation photo No. 1996.253.6996 As part of the permanently forward deployed force in Japan, Carrier Air Wing Five (CVW-5) code NF was assigned to CV-41 USS MIDWAY. www.gonavy.jp/CVW-NF2f.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1973.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1974.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1975.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1976.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1977.html For up to five years during the period from January 1973 to December 1977; A-6A 155718 of VA-115 as Modex 511 was part of CVW-5 based at NAF Atsugi, Japan. While CV-41 USS MIDWAY was home ported at Yokosuka, Japan. A-6A 155718, VA-115, Modex 511 was replaced by an A-6E during 1977. 1980 British spotters sighting report for A-6E 155718 of VA-35 'Panthers' Modex 504 with code AJ of CVW-8: homepage.ntlworld.com/nigel.sadler1/page_article_CVN-68%2... This was aboard CVN-68 - USS NIMITZ anchored off Portsmouth harbor, England, UK between 25th & 29th September 1980 A-6E 155718, wearing Modex code 504, was part of VA-35 'Black Panthers' with CVW-8 (code AJ) aboard CVN-68 USS NIMITZ some time before or between August 29 & October 17 1980 for a North Atlantic deployment and NATO exercise Teamwork 80. www.gonavy.jp/CVW-AJf.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW8-AJ1980.html A-6E 155718 was with US Marine Corps unit VMA(AW)-224 ‘Fighting Bengals’ as Modex 505 tail code WK & based at MCAS Iwakuni, Japan between April & 25 Sept 1989. This was part of US Marine Corps Marine Air Group Twelve. seagull77.web.infoseek.co.jp/MAG12/mag12.html A-6E 155718 may have been transferred to VMA (AW)-332 (code EA) A-6E Intruder 155718 was with VA-65 ‘Tigers’ as Modex 501 when it took part in Operations 'Desert Shield' & 'Desert Storm' firstly protectiing the Arabian Gulf then later the freeing of Kuwait from the grip of invasion and subsequent defeat of enemy Iraq forces within its own territory: www.gonavy.jp/CVW8-AJ1990.html VA-65 was part of Carrier Air Wing Eight (CVW-8) code AJ aboard CVN-71 USS THEODORE ROOSEVELT between December 28, 1990 & June 28, 1991. Commercially available airborne color picture of A-6E 155718 dated 23 April 1990: www.cloud9photography.us/Military-Aviation-10/Grumman-A-6... A-6USN 00002 Grumman A-6 Intruder USN 155718 USS Theodore Roosevelt 23 April 1990 by Robert L Lawson A 1994 sighting report for A-6E 155718 at Norfolk Naval Air Depot, Virginia: www.scramble.nl/showreports.htm (Click on 'North America' on left then within the list ‘United States of America’, scroll down to ‘Norfolk (VA)’ then click on ‘1994’ to view – scroll down again to entry) NAS Norfolk (VA), 41st International Azelea Festival Air Show. 24 April 1994. NAD Storage: A-6E/KA-6D : (Among fifteen Intruders is recorded - ) 155718/ AD-570 The entry is interpreted that A-6E 155718 was seen marked with tail code AD of VA-42 ‘Thunderbolts’, marked Modex 570, and had been part of the US East coast based Fleet Requirements Squadron that trained Intruder aviators and maintainers, after being placed in store before eventual decision on disposal. There's no known record of it being retired to AMARC storage in Arizona. Further info that might reveal more on the service history of A-6A/E 155718 and its eventual fate may possibly be accessed by use of the US Freedom of Information Act by ANY interested citizen. (not just U.S.) foia.navy.mil/OnlineFoiaRequestForm2.asp
